## Intro

## Vigilance




### PVT Differences

```{r PVT_Differences, message=FALSE, warning = FALSE}
##########################################
  ### PVT/VIGILANCE/RT ###
#########################################

#Download PVT data (this datafile is made in 'preprocessing')
data <- read.csv(paste0(Dir, "PVT.csv"), header = TRUE, sep = )
data$RT <- 1/(data$RT/1000) # mean 1/RT

## CREATE DATAFRAME  with the MeanRT per ID, Day, Condition
PVT <- as.data.frame(group_by(data, Test, Day, Condition, ID) %>%
  summarise(
    count = n(),
    Vigilance = mean(RT, na.rm = TRUE)))
PVT <- PVT[!(PVT$ID==49),] # to make both conditions even amount of participants

# make factors
PVT$Day <- factor(PVT$Day)
PVT$ID <- factor(PVT$ID)
PVT$Condition <- factor(PVT$Condition)
names(PVT)[names(PVT)=="Test"] <- "Session"
PVT$Session <- as.factor(PVT$Session)

### CHECKING ASSUMPTIONS ####
# Session x Condition 2-way ANOVA with interaction effect (what Borrogan did)
model <- aov(Vigilance ~ Condition * Day * Session, data= PVT)
# HOMOGENEITY OF VARIANCE
plot(model, 1) # residuqls vs fits plot shows no evident relationship residuals and fitted values (Vigilances of groups)
leveneTest(Vigilance~ Day * Condition, data= PVT) # nono sign
# NORMALITY
aov_residuals <- residuals (object=model)
shapiro.test(x=aov_residuals) # sign, but OK: n>30
ggqqplot(PVT, "Vigilance", ggtheme = theme_bw()) +
  facet_grid(Day ~ Condition) # clearly not normal



## ANALYSIS
three_w <- lm(Vigilance ~ Session*Condition*Day, data= PVT)
model <- aov(three_w)
summary(model)# non sign so no post-hoc tests
report(model)

d<-melt(data.frame(RT=c(PVT$Vigilance))) # we melt to wide format
distribution_plot (d, 'Vigilance') # much better
qqPlot(PVT$Vigilance) # much better





# OUTLIERS
summary(PVT$Vigilance)
outliers <- boxplot(PVT$Vigilance, plot=FALSE)$out
# remove 
PVT<- PVT[-which(PVT$Vigilance %in% outliers),]# Result the SAME for data with or without outliers: because it is glmer
# but removing the outliers makes visualisations much more readable
three_w <- lm(Vigilance ~ Session*Condition*Day, data= PVT)
emVigilances1<- emmeans(three_w, pairwise ~ Session*Condition*Day, adjust ="fdr", type='response')
emmean_dataframe <- summary(emmeans1)$emmeans

sum <- sum_3 (PVT, 'Day', 'Condition', 'Session', 'Vigilance')

## VISUALISATION
# boxplot 
ggboxplot(
  PVT, x = "Condition", y = "Vigilance",
  color = "Session", palette = "jco",
  facet.by = "Day", short.panel.labs = FALSE)



Day.labs <- c("Day 1", "Day 2")
names(Day.labs) <- c("1", "2")

## plot with error bars
pl <- plotty(PVT, emmean_dataframe, 'Session', 'Vigilance', 'Condition', 'emmean', 'Vigilance') +
 facet_grid(.~Day, labeller = labeller(Day=Day.labs))+
 scale_x_discrete(labels=c("Session 1", "Session 2"))
ggsave(pl, file=paste0(plotPrefix, "PVT_Plot.jpg"), width = 2500, height = 1500, dpi = 300, units = "px")
pl

```

## Subjective CF: VAS-f

= subjective measure of fatigue on 1-10 scale
we want to know if there is a difference in VAS before and after Test

```{r VASf, message=FALSE, warning = FALSE}
##########################################
  ### VAS-f: fatigue ###
#########################################

#### DOWNLOAD + CLEAN DATA ####
data <- read.csv(paste0(Dir, "VAS.csv"), header = TRUE, sep = )
data <-data[(grepl("quantised", data$Question.Key)),] #VAS has 'quantised: 1-11 instead of 0-10
# create dataframe
VAS <- as.data.frame(group_by(data, Test, Day, Condition, ID) %>%
  summarise(
    count = n(),
    Mean = mean(Response, na.rm = TRUE))) 

#factors
VAS$Day <- as.factor(VAS$Day)
VAS$Condition <- as.factor(VAS$Condition)
VAS$ID <- as.factor(VAS$ID)
names(VAS)[names(VAS)=="Test"] <- "Session"
VAS$Session <- as.factor(VAS$Session)

### CHECKING ASSUMPTIONS ####
# Session x Condition 2-way ANOVA with interaction effect (what Borrogan did)
model <- aov(Mean ~ Condition * Day, data= VAS)
summary(model)# no sign! this is good, means vigilance was same in all conditions
# HOMOGENEITY OF VARIANCE
leveneTest(Mean~ Session * Condition, data= VAS) # no homogeneity! problem! 
plot(model, 1) # residuqls vs fits plot shows no evident relationship residuals and fitted values (means of groups)
# NORMALITY
aov_residuals <- residuals (object=model)
shapiro.test(x=aov_residuals) #  
#visualisation
plot(model, 2) #normal
ggqqplot(VAS, "Mean", ggtheme = theme_bw()) +
  facet_grid(Day ~ Condition)#  very obviously NOT a normal distribution
# SPHERICITY: ok, bc all conditions 2 levels

#visualise
d<-melt(data.frame(VAS=c(VAS$Mean))) # we melt to wide format
distribution_plot (d, 'Mean')
qqPlot(VAS$Mean) 


#### repeated-measures ANOVA ####
three_w <- lm(Mean ~ Session*Condition*Day, data= VAS)
model <- aov(three_w)
summary(model)
report(model)

pw2<- VAS %>%
  group_by (Condition)%>%
  pairwise_t_test(Mean~Session, paired=TRUE,
                  p.adjust.method='bonferroni')
data.frame(pw2)

emmeans1<- emmeans(three_w, pairwise ~ Session*Condition*Day, adjust ="fdr", type = "response")
emmean_dataframe <- summary(emmeans1)$emmeans
emmeans1

sum <- sum_3 (VAS, 'Session', 'Condition', 'Day', 'Mean')

## VISUALISATION
# boxplot 
ggboxplot(
  VAS, x = "Condition", y = "Mean",
  color = "Session", palette = "jco",
  facet.by = "Day", short.panel.labs = FALSE)

## plot with error bars
max_y<-max(VAS$Mean)
Day.labs <- c("Day 1", "Day 2")
names(Day.labs) <- c("1", "2")
pl <- plotty(VAS, emmean_dataframe, 'Session', 'Mean', 'Condition', 'emmean', 'VAS-f') +
 facet_grid(.~Day, labeller = labeller(Day=Day.labs))+
scale_x_discrete(labels=c("Session 1", "Session 2"))+
  ylab("Subjective CF")
ggsave(pl, file=paste0(plotPrefix, "VAS_Plot.jpg"), width = 2500, height = 1500, dpi = 300, units = "px")
pl

two_w <- lm(Mean ~ Session*Condition, data= VAS)
emmeans1<- emmeans(three_w, pairwise ~ Session*Condition, adjust ="fdr", type = "response")
emmean_dataframe <- summary(emmeans1)$emmeans
emmeans1

sum <- sum_2 (VAS, 'Session', 'Condition', 'Mean')
pl <- plotty(VAS, emmean_dataframe, 'Condition', 'Mean', 'Session', 'emmean', 'VAS-f')+
  scale_fill_manual(values = c("blue", 'red'), #colours used in plot
                    name='', labels= c('Session 1', 'Session 2'))+
  ylab("Subjective CF")
pl

```

## Objective CF

* We will test  the evolution of Performance (weighted accuracy) during TloadDback with Condition (HCL/LCL) and Time (t1-t3) as within-subject factors.
* interested in main effect e.g. t1>t4 and Condition x Time interaction on the Acc

```{r Performance, message=FALSE, warning = FALSE}
##########################################
  ### PERFORMANCE/ ACCURACY/ OBJECTIVE CF ###
#########################################

#### DOWNLOAD + CLEAN DATA ####
data<- read.csv(paste0(Dir, "EXP.csv"), header = TRUE, sep = )
# we remove rows that have prop_correct == NA , because these are lines in the data where the ERROR message was shown (accuracy=0)
data <- data[!is.na(data$prop_correct),]
# create a trial.index that goes from 1 to the number of trials:  not every participant has equal amount of trials, depends on their speed/accuracy
for (i in 1:97) { data$trial.index[data$ID==i]= 1:length(unique(data$Trial.Index[data$ID ==i]))}
# create var Time that indicates if it is part of t1, t2, t3. t1 is the first 40%, t2 middle 20%, t3 last 40% 
# we work with percentages because the #trials differs per ptt AND per day: 
for (i in 1:97) {
  data$Time[data$ID ==i & data$Day==1] = 2 # day 1
  data$Time[data$ID ==i & data$Day==1 & data$trial.index<(0.6* length(data$trial.index[data$Day==1 & data$ID==i])) ] = "middle"
  data$Time[data$ID ==i & data$Day==1 & data$trial.index<(0.4* length(data$trial.index[data$Day==1 & data$ID==i])) ] = 1
  data$Time[data$ID ==i & data$Day==2] = 2 # day 2
  data$Time[data$ID ==i & data$Day==2 & data$trial.index<(0.6* length(data$trial.index[data$Day==2 & data$ID==i])) ] = "middle"
  data$Time[data$ID ==i & data$Day==2 & data$trial.index<(0.4* length(data$trial.index[data$Day==2 & data$ID==i])) ] = 1
}
#remove 'middle'
data <- data[!(data$Time=="middle"),]
# CREATE DATAFRAME, with the Mean prop_correct per ID, Time, Day, Condition
EXP <- as.data.frame (group_by(data, Condition, Day, Time, ID) %>%
  summarise(
    count = n(),
    Mean = mean(prop_correct, na.rm = TRUE)))
 EXP <- EXP[!(EXP$ID==49),]

# set factors
EXP$Time <- as.factor(EXP$Time)
EXP$Condition <- as.factor(EXP$Condition)
EXP$Day <- as.factor(EXP$Day)
EXP$ID <- as.factor(EXP$ID)


### CHECKING ASSUMPTIONS ####
# Time x Condition 2-way ANOVA with interaction effect
model <- aov(Mean ~ Condition*Time, data= EXP)
## HOMOGENEITY OF VARIANCE
leveneTest(Mean~ Time * Condition, data= EXP) # no homogeneity! problem! 
box_m(EXP[, 'Mean', drop=FALSE], EXP$Condition) # no homogeneity of variance
plot(model, 1) # residuqls vs fits plot shows no evident relationship residuals and fitted values (means of groups)

## NORMALITY
aov_residuals <- residuals (object=model)
shapiro.test(x=aov_residuals) # no normality! 
ggqqplot(EXP, "Mean", ggtheme = theme_bw()) +
  facet_grid(Time ~ Condition)#  very obviously NOT a normal distribution

#visualise
d<-melt(data.frame(EXP=c(EXP$Mean))) # we melt to wide format
distribution_plot (d, 'Mean')


#### repeated-measures ANOVA ####
three_w <- lm(Mean ~ Time*Condition*Day, data= EXP)
model <- aov(three_w)
summary(model)
report(model)

# sum_2(EXP, 'Time', 'Condition', 'Mean')
# pw2<- EXP %>%
#   group_by (Condition)%>%
#   pairwise_t_test(Mean~Time, paired=TRUE,
#                   p.adjust.method='bonferroni')
# data.frame(pw2)

sum_2(EXP, 'Time', 'Day', 'Mean')
sum_3(EXP, 'Time', 'Condition', 'Day', 'Mean')
pw2<- EXP %>%
  group_by (Day)%>%
  pairwise_t_test(Mean~Time, paired=TRUE,
                  p.adjust.method='bonferroni')
data.frame(pw2)


emmeans1<- emmeans(three_w, pairwise ~ Time*Condition*Day, adjust ="fdr", type = "response")
emmean_dataframe <- summary(emmeans1)$emmeans
emmeans1

sum<- sum_3 (EXP, 'Time', 'Condition', 'Day', 'Mean')

## VISUALISATION
# boxplot 
ggboxplot(
  EXP, x = "Condition", y = "Mean",
  color = "Time", palette = "jco",
  facet.by = "Day", short.panel.labs = FALSE)

## plot with error bars
Day.labs <- c("Day 1", "Day 2")
names(Day.labs) <- c("1", "2")
pl <- plotty(EXP, emmean_dataframe, 'Time', 'Mean', 'Condition', 'emmean', 'Performance') +
 facet_grid(.~Day, labeller = labeller(Day=Day.labs))+
scale_x_discrete(labels=c("T 1", "T 2"))+
  ylab("Performance")
ggsave(pl, file=paste0(plotPrefix, "EXP_Plot.jpg"), width = 2500, height = 1500, dpi = 300, units = "px")
pl
```

## COMPONENTS
```{r Components, message=FALSE, warning = FALSE}
### COMPONENTS (Color/Pic)####

# evolution over time for 2 components of the task
# Pics: decide if big/small. Color: decide if same as DualBack: more Working Memory
EXP1 <- as.data.frame (group_by(data, Condition, Day, Time, ID, Stim) %>%
  summarise(
    count = n(),
    Mean = mean(accuracy, na.rm = TRUE) ))
# set factors
EXP1$Time <- as.factor(EXP1$Time)
EXP1$Condition <- as.factor(EXP1$Condition)
EXP1$Day <- as.factor(EXP1$Day)
EXP1$ID <- as.factor(EXP1$ID)
EXP1$Stim <- as.factor(EXP1$Stim)

#### repeated-measures ANOVA ####
two_w <- lm(Mean ~ Time*Stim, data= EXP1)
model <- aov(two_w)
summary(model)
report(model)
three_w <- lm(Mean~Time * Stim * Condition, data=EXP1)
emmeans1<- emmeans(two_w, pairwise ~ Time*Stim, adjust ="fdr", type = "response")
emmean_dataframe <- summary(emmeans1)$emmeans
emmeans1

pw2<- EXP1 %>%
  group_by (Time)%>%
  pairwise_t_test(Mean~Stim, paired=TRUE,
                  p.adjust.method='bonferroni')
data.frame(pw2)

sum <- sum_2 (EXP1, 'Stim','Time', 'Mean')
sum

ggboxplot(
  EXP1, x = "Time", y = "Mean",
  color = "Stim", palette = "jco",
   short.panel.labs = FALSE)

pl <- plotty(EXP1, emmean_dataframe, 'Time', 'Mean', 'Stim', 'emmean', 'Components')+
  ylab("Performance")+
scale_x_discrete(labels=c("T 1", "T 2"))
ggsave(pl, file=paste0(plotPrefix, "EXP_Plot.jpg"), width = 2500, height = 1500, dpi = 300, units = "px")
pl
```
